questions.question: Cybersecurity attacks are always committed for financial gain.
Which of the following attacks are commonly used to extort money from an organisation?
Which of the following are non-financial examples of why cybersecurity attacks are performed?

choices.answer: Stealing intellectual property from a rival business.
Trying to out do an organisation’s cybersecurity measures
Revenge by employees who feel mistreated by a business.

questions.question: Which of the following are common ways of disrupting an online shopping website?
What do we mean by “social engineering”?

choices.answer: Gaining access to a system without the permission of the owner.
Manipulating individuals into handing over private information.
Misdirecting users to a fraudulent/fake website
Inserting yourself into the middle of a communication

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common example of a social engineering threat?
The term “Malware” and “Virus” mean the same thing.
Which of the following are common examples of malware threats?
What's the main difference between viruses and worms?

choices.answer: Viruses attach themselves to software or file in order to spread.
A worms monitors users action to steal information
Worms attach themselves to software or file in order to spread.

questions.question: How does ransomware usually lock victims out of their files?

choices.answer: Locks victim out from accessing their data

questions.question: What is the difference between a white hat hacker and a black hat hacker?

choices.answer: A white hat hacker is hired by a business to test hack
A black hat hacker is hired by a business to hack their own system to test
A white hat hacker reads or copies data when they gain access to it
A black hat hacker only reads or copies data when they gain access to it

questions.question: Which of the following are examples of deliberate internal threats?
Which of the following are examples of accidental internal threats?
Why might someone intentionally steal or leak information?

choices.answer: By mistake due to a phishing attack.
Due to visiting an untrustworthy website.
Being disgruntled due to being made redundant.

questions.question: How might an employee unintentionally disclose data?

choices.answer: Being tricked by a phishing email.
Due to spyware being installed on their system.

questions.question: How might visiting an untrustworthy website lead to a security threat?

choices.answer: The site may trick users into revealing information.
Downloads might infect the user's system with malware.
The site may contain offensive material
The site might be a whistleblowing site for leaking information.

questions.question: How frequently should backups be taken?
Which of the following would count as a remote backup?

choices.answer: On a separate hard disk on the same computer.
A USB stick stored in a locked safe.
A USB stick kept in another building.

questions.question: Why is stored data encrypted?

choices.answer: If data is stolen it is still unreadable.
So you don't have to password protect it.

questions.question: A grey-hat hacker is someone that a business hires to identify vulnerabilities and suggest improvements
What are two common vulnerabilities identified by penetration testing?

choices.answer: Users taking confidential data out of the business.
